Comprehensive Temperature Conversion Charts

What is gas mark 4 in a fan oven?

Gas mark 4 is equivalent to 180Â°C in a fan oven. This temperature is perfect for baking cakes, cookies, and roasting vegetables.

450 fahrenheit to celsius fan oven conversion

450Â°F converts to approximately 230Â°C in a conventional oven. For a fan oven, reduce by 20Â°C to get 210Â°C.

How to convert 180Â°C conventional to fan oven

To convert 180Â°C from conventional to fan oven, reduce the temperature by 20Â°C. The fan oven equivalent is 160Â°C.

What is gas mark 6 in a fan oven?

Gas mark 6 is equivalent to 200Â°C in a fan oven. This temperature is perfect for roasting meats and baking bread.

350 fahrenheit to celsius fan oven

350Â°F converts to approximately 175Â°C in a conventional oven. For a fan oven, reduce by 20Â°C to get 155Â°C.

Food-Specific Conversion Guide

Breads & Pizza

  • Artisan bread: 230Â°C fan (250Â°C conventional)
  • Pizza: 220-240Â°C fan, bake directly on stone
  • Quick breads: Reduce time by 15%

Tip: Steam injection helps crust development in fan ovens

Cakes & Pastries

  • Sponge cakes: 160Â°C fan, check 5 min early
  • Butter cakes: 170Â°C fan, use middle rack
  • Puff pastry: 200Â°C fan for maximum rise

Tip: Reduce sugar slightly as fan ovens promote browning

Meats & Roasts

  • Whole chicken: 180Â°C fan, 20% less time
  • Beef roast: 160Â°C fan for medium-rare
  • Fish: 150Â°C fan, watch carefully

Tip: Always use meat thermometer for perfect results

Professional Baking Tips for Fan Ovens

1. Oven Thermometer is Essential

Most ovens run hot or cold. For precision baking, place an independent oven thermometer in the center of your oven to verify actual temperature.

2. Adjust Baking Times

As a general rule, reduce baking times by 10-15% when using fan mode. Start checking for doneness earlier than recipe suggests.

3. Rack Position Matters

Middle rack works best for most baking. For multiple racks, rotate pans halfway through baking for even results.

4. Avoid Overcrowding

Fan ovens need good air circulation. Leave at least 2 inches between pans and avoid covering oven racks with foil.

5. Humidity Control

Fan ovens can dry foods faster. For moist cakes, place a pan of water in the bottom of the oven during baking.

6. High Altitude Adjustments

At elevations above 900m (3000ft), you may need additional temperature reductions of 5-10Â°C in fan ovens.

7. Account for Brand Variations

Every oven brand has a slightly different fan speed. If your fan oven is particularly powerful (like some professional models), you may need to reduce the temperature by 25Â°C instead of the standard 20Â°C.

8. Always Preheat Fully

Fan ovens reach temperature faster, but for baking delicate items like soufflÃ©s or cakes, wait at least 15 minutes after the 'at temperature' light goes off to ensure the oven walls are fully heated.

Fan Oven Conversion FAQs

Why do fan ovens need lower temperatures?

Fan ovens circulate hot air continuously, creating more efficient heat transfer to your food. The 20Â°C reduction compensates for this increased efficiency, preventing overcooking or burning.

How do I know if my fan oven runs hot or cold?

Place an oven thermometer in the center of your oven. Set to 180Â°C fan and let preheat for 20 minutes. Check thermometer reading through the window. If it's more than 10Â°C different, you may need to adjust your settings.

Should I reduce both temperature and time?

Yes, for most recipes you should reduce temperature by 20Â°C (from conventional to fan) and reduce time by 10-15% (start checking early).

Are all fan ovens the same?

While the 20Â°C rule works for most fan ovens, there can be variations. Standard fan ovens typically need -20Â°C adjustment, while multi-function/combi ovens may need -10 to -30Â°C adjustments.

What is 425Â°F in a fan oven?

425Â°F converts to approximately 220Â°C in a conventional oven. For a fan oven, reduce by 20Â°C to get 200Â°C.

How to convert gas mark to fan oven?

Use our conversion chart above. Generally, gas mark 4 = 180Â°C fan, gas mark 6 = 200Â°C fan, and gas mark 2 = 150Â°C fan.

Fan ovens circulate hot air continuously, creating more efficient heat transfer to your food. This means:

  • Heat reaches all surfaces of the food more evenly
  • No cold spots in the oven cavity
  • Faster cooking times overall

The 20Â°C reduction compensates for this increased efficiency, preventing overcooking or burning.

Follow this simple test:

  1. Place an oven thermometer in the center of your oven
  2. Set to 180Â°C fan and let preheat for 20 minutes
  3. Check thermometer reading through the window

If it's more than 10Â°C different from set temperature, you may need to adjust your settings or have your oven calibrated.

  • Reduce temperature by 20Â°C (from conventional to fan)
  • Reduce time by 10-15% (start checking early)

However, some delicate items like soufflÃ©s or custards may only need temperature adjustment. Experience will help you judge best.

Oven TypeTypical Adjustment
